lines: Your car has to be taken in for some minor repair work. The work will not cost you any appreciable amount of money, but it will be an inconvenience, since you will have to drop the car off at the repair shop early in the morning and
You call in to make an appointment, and the service representative tells you that repairs are made on a first-come, first-served basis.
#BRING THE CAR IN TO BE FIXED
#BRING THE CAR IN TO BE FIXED
If it isn't major, you can probably live with it, right? Wrong! CLANK! CLANK! GRIND! SPUTTER! COUGH! Silence! Your car is no longer among the living. Towing, repair and service charges cost $1000.
When will you bring the car in?
#LATE MORNING ON THE WAY TO WORK

There is a long line of people already in front of you. Apparently, they have been LIVING at the service station, anticipating a car repair fad that seems to be sweeping the area. They are all holding coupons which ran in the local paper.
Since you don't have one, you will be paying regular prices. To make matters worse, since you do not have an appointment any place else, you cannot take your car elsewhere to be fixed that day.
#SET UP CAMP AND WAIT IN LINE

Finally, it is your turn to visit the sacred car repair mechanic. His first words of wisdom are, "Do you have an appointment?" You explain to him that you were told that repairs were made on a first-come, first-served basis. You get the
feeling that he doesn't believe that you ever had such a telephone conversation.
He tells you, "I'm sorry. That's the way we have been doing it for years." At this point you can:

Tch! Tch! That won't get you anywhere. The mechanic tells you there is nothing he can do except give you an appointment. There is one available three weeks from next Friday. Scheduling a private luncheon with the president of the United
#TRY TO FIND ANOTHER PLACE TO FIX THE CAR
Your car's performance deteriorates rapidly in the three-week time period. Your repair bill, which should have been about $50, will cost you a cool, cruel, $1000.
#ASK TO SPEAK TO THIS PERSON'S SUPERVISOR
The mechanic says, "Have a nice day!"
You are much too angry to get anywhere with this person's supervisor. You made the appointment, you had the car fixed and this is the price of the repairs.
#PAY THE MONEY AND FORGET ABOUT IT
Your crying takes the supervisor by surprise. He begins to panic. He turns to the mechanic, mumbles a few words, and says, "Okay, okay. No charge for the repair work!"
Are you ashamed of the way you behaved just to get your way?
Believe me, he'll get over it.
You bring the garage to small claims court. The result of the action is:
You win your case plus $500 punitive damages! Like the man says, "If you don't like the services you are getting at your local garage, don't take the matter into your own hands -- take 'em to court."
You lose! Sorry. Now you have to pay the $1000

On the way out of the service station, you hear your car making peculiar noises...CLANK! CLANK! GRIND! SPUTTER! COUGH! Silence! Your car is no longer among the living. Towing, repair and service charges cost $1000.

You try to control your voice, which still reflects your earlier anger, but there is no swaying the mechanic. He keeps referring to the appointment book and muttering that all of his assistants are on vacation over the next couple of
weeks. At this point you can:
It is easy to see that you are an optimist! You are greeted by a mechanic who is clearly holding a book with the word APPOINTMENTS in big letters across the front.

You clearly recall hearing that cars would be taken on a first-come, first-served basis. Perhaps they are running a beauty parlor in the back of the garage. Perhaps they USED to do service by appointment and now they just keep the book

Nope! It is a bona fide appointment book. The mechanic apologizes for the misunderstanding. He sees that you are a calm person and is prepared to treat you with courtesy. He can give you an appointment for three weeks from Friday.

Not only are you calm, but you are also quite unassertive (with all due respect). Over the next three weeks, your car's health deteriorates rapidly. The cost of the repair bill when you finally DO get to your appointment is $1000.

The supervisor greets you, and you explain your predicament. Surely, you can't be held accountable for a mistake that was made on their end. The supervisor relates (politely) that there is no way to be sure on which end the error was
made. You will have to take an appointment like everyone else.
Your persistence pays off. The supervisor's supervisor says that you can have an appointment later in the week. Does this satisfy you?
Okay. During the course of the next week, your car breaks down. The cost of the repairs is $400.
Okay, okay. You are a tough person to please, even if you are calm. You can have your appointment today. Sticking to your guns paid off!
